messageBody:
If you're willing to have all of your tests subclass from an AbstractTestCase, then you can do this fairly simply. In your AbstractTestCase, just override run(TestResult) and run(). In the body of the first, register your TestListener on the TestResult and call super.run(). In the second, create a new TestResult and pass it to the first.

Kent,

Thanks for the reply. Would you consider adding something like this in JUnit 4 so it is there if someone like me needs it someday? I'd need to get this working now with 3.8.1 but would still be nice to have it in the future supported by the framework more directly.

I thought about modifying the TestCase tearDown method to call my "listener" code but then I realized not all tests might do the super.tearDown call if they override the method. As I haven't written all the tests I want to collect data for I can't control that. So I am thinking of just modifying the TestResult class that collects the results and adding my listener there as it supports TestListeners. Does anyone see problems with that? This would mean I take the junit source, add my code and build the jar to use with the projects I want to collect data for.

Thanks,

-Teemu
